intro: Lepeostegeres elmeri, commonly known as the Elmer's mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees, primarily in the Pacific Northwest of the United States. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and has a distinctive appearance with small, oval-shaped leaves and white, fleshy berries that are edible for some bird species. The plant relies on its host for water and nutrients but can photosynthesize to some extent. It plays an important ecological role in forest ecosystems by providing food for birds and contributing to the biodiversity of its habitat.
